criteria: Understanding of the Definition of Mean
descriptions: Student does not demonstrate an understanding of the definition of the mean of a discrete random variable.
Student shows minimal understanding of the definition, with significant misconceptions.
Student demonstrates a partial understanding of the definition, but struggles to explain it accurately.
Student generally understands the definition of the mean of a discrete random variable and can explain it with some clarity.
Student clearly understands and accurately explains the definition of the mean of a discrete random variable.
Student demonstrates a comprehensive understanding of the definition, can explain it clearly, and can provide examples and non-examples.
Student cannot determine the mean for a given discrete random variable.
Student attempts to determine the mean, but the approach is fundamentally flawed.
Student makes significant errors in the process of determining the mean.
Student can determine the mean with some errors or inefficiencies in the calculations.
Student accurately determines the mean for a discrete random variable with clear and correct calculations.
Student accurately and efficiently determines the mean, and can explain the process and justify the answer.
Student cannot apply the concept of mean to any practical scenario.
Student struggles to relate the concept of mean to real-world examples.
Student shows a limited ability to contextualize the mean within practical problems.
Student can apply the concept of mean to solve basic problems, showing some understanding of its practical use.
Student applies the concept of mean to solve complex problems effectively.
Student can apply the concept of mean in different contexts, explains its significance, and relates it to other statistical concepts.
